FIGREF0.text: LL, CJ and YY conceived and guided the project. YY, CS, MY carried out the experiments and 28 analyzed the data. JL, FH, JY, FW, ZZ, ZW, MC, WW, RZ, YL, LX, LP, JW, HZ, ZX and HW collected 29 clinical samples and the data. GFG provided critical idea and assistant. YY wrote the manuscript. All 30 the authors have read and approved the manuscript.

FIGREF1.text: This study was supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (Grant 33 81802004), Ministry of Science and Technology (2020YFC0846300), the National Science and 34 Technology Major Project (Grants 2018ZX10711001, 2017ZX10204401 and 2017ZX10103011), SZSM201512005), the Chinese Academy of Medical Sciences Innovation Fund for Medical Sciences 38 (grant 2017-I2M-1-009) and the National Natural Science Foundation of China (Grant 81788101) 39 40 Disclosure of potential conflicts of interest41We declare no competing interests. biomarkers for disease severity and progression.

FIGREF2.text: To identify biomarkers for disease severity and progression of COVID-19.

FIGREF3.text: Forty-eight cytokines in the plasma samples from 50 COVID-19 cases including 11 critically 50 ill, 25 severe and 14 moderate patients were measured and analyzed in combination with clinical data.51Results Fourteen cytokines were found to be significantly elevated in COVID-19 cases and showed 52 different expression profiles in patients with different disease severity. Moreover, expression levels of 53 IP-10, MCP-3, HGF, MIG and MIP-1α, which were shown to be highly associated with disease 54 severity during disease progression, were remarkably higher in critically ill patients, followed by severe 55 and then the moderate patients. Serial detection of the five cytokines in 16 cases showed that 56 continuously high levels were associated with deteriorated progression of disease and fatal outcome.

FIGREF4.text: IP-10 and MCP-3 were excellent predictors for the progression of COVID-19, and the 58 combination of the two cytokines showed the biggest area under the curve (AUC) of the 59 receiver-operating characteristics (ROC) calculations with a value of 0.99. Introduction 87 Coronaviruses are the largest known viruses with a single positive-sense genome of about 31 Kb

FIGREF5.text: Treatment of SARS-CoV-2 infection, and analyzed the expression profiles of plasma cytokines in 110 combination with clinical data in detail. 111 112 Patient information and data collection 114 Subjects presented in this study were hospitalized COVID-19 patients (N=50), including 11 critically 115 ill, 25 severe and 14 moderate patients defined according to China National Health Commission 116 Guidelines for Diagnosis and Treatment of 2019-nCoV infection. Healthy controls (N=8) were also 117 included. Clinical information and laboratory result were collected at the earliest time-point after 118 hospital admission. The study protocol was approved by the Ethics Committees of Shenzhen Third 119 People's Hospital (SZTHEC2016001). Verbal informed consents were obtained from all patients or 120 patients family members of 2019-nCoV and H7N9 infections due to the special circumstances that pens 121 and papers were not allowed to be brought into containment facilities. The study was conducted in 122 accordance with the International Conference on Harmonisation Guidelines for Good Clinical Practice 123 and the Declaration of Helsinki and institutional ethics guidelines. 124 125 Disease severity classification 126 Disease severity classification and Murray Score calculation were evaluated as previously reported 26 . 127 Severity of 2019-nCoV infection was graded according to China National Health Commission 128 Guidelines for Diagnosis and Treatment of SARS-CoV-2 infection (seventh version). Laboratory 129 confirmed patients with fever, respiratory manifestations and radiological findings indicative of 130 pneumonia were considered moderate cases (COVID-19-M). Laboratory confirmed patients who met 131 any of the following were considered to have severe COVID-19 (COVID-19-S): 1) respiratory distress 132 (respiration rate ≥ 30/min; 2) resting oxygen saturation ≤ 93%, or 3) arterial oxygen partial pressure (PaO2) / fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) ≤ 300 mmHg (1 mmHg = 0.133 kPa). Laboratory 134 confirmed patients who had any of the following were considered critically ill (COVID-19-C): 1) 135 respiratory failure requiring mechanical ventilation, 2) shock, or 3) failure of other organs requiring 136 intensive care unit (ICU). 137 138 Quantification of hypoxia and Murray Score 139 The partial pressure of oxygen (PaO2) in arterial blood taken from the patients at various time-points 140 after hospitalization is measured by the ABL90 blood gas analyzer (Radiometer). The fraction of 141 inspired oxygen (FiO2) is calculated by the following formula: FiO2 = (21 + oxygen flow (in units of 142 l/min) × 4) / 100. The PaO2/FiO2 ratio (in units of mmHg) is calculated by dividing the PaO2 value 143 with the FiO2 value. A PaO2/FiO2 ratio less than or equal to 100 mmHg is considered one of the 144 criteria for severe acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). Murray Score were calculated as plasma of patients with laboratory-confirmed COVID-19 cases (N=50) were collected at the 149 earliest possible time-point after hospitalization and thereafter. The plasma of healthy subjects (N=8) 150 were included as the negative control group. The concentrations of 48 cytokines were measured using 151 Bio-Plex Pro Human Cytokine Screening Panel (Bio-Rad) as previously reported 26 .152 Statistical analysis 154 Chi-square and Analysis of Variance (ANOVA) tests were used to compare the indicated rates and the 155 plasma cytokine levels among the moderate, severe and critical groups. The Spearman rank correlation 156 coefficient was used for linear correlation analysis between the expression level of plasma cytokine and 157 Murray score. The area under the receiver operating characteristic (ROC) curve (AUC) of plasma 158 cytokine levels was estimated for the patients developing ARDS or not. Moreover, the combined values 159 for the prediction of developing ARDS was calculated using binary logistic regression. All statistical 160 tests were calculated using SPSS 20.0 for Windows (IBM, Chicago, USA). P value less than 0.05 was 161 considered statistically significant.

FIGREF6.text: of 50 patients with 29 males (58%) were enrolled in our study. These patients were further 166 divided into three groups of critically ill, severe and moderate based on disease severity according to 167 the China National Health Commission Guidelines for Diagnosis and Treatment of SARS-CoV-2 168 infection. The median age of these patients was 62, and ranged from 22 to 78 years-old (

FIGREF8.text: profile of cytokines in patients with different disease severity 181 Firstly, we analyzed the expression profile of the COVID-19 patients upon admission. Results showed 182 that a total of 30 cytokines including both pro-and anti-inflammatory significantly elevated in 183 COVID-19 patients upon admission, when compared with the healthy control (Figure S1). Then the differential expression profile of patients with different disease severity at different phase of disease 185 were further analyzed (Figure 1 and Figure S2). Time-points of sample collection were stratified into 186 three groups according to the disease progression as previously reported 28 , the first 7 days after illness 187 onset (0~7 d.a.o), between 8 and 14 days following illness onset (8~14 d.a.o), and during the recovery 188 phase from 15 days after disease onset (≥ 15 d.a.o). Fourteen cytokines including IL-1β (interleukin, chemotactic protein-3), MIG (monokine induced gamma interferon), M-CSF (macrophage 191 colony stimulating factor), G-CSF (granulocyte colony-stimulating factor), MIP-1α 192 (macrophage inflammatory protein 1 alpha), MIP-1β, CTACK (cutaneous T-cell-attracting chemokine) 193 and IP-10 (interferon gamma induced protein 10) showed differential expression levels among the 194 patients with different disease severity (Figure 1). Expression levels of IP-10, HGF and MCP-3 were 195 highest in critically ill patients, followed by severe patients, and then the moderate in all groups of 196 sample collection time-points. Differential expressions of IL-1ra and M-CSF were mainly found in the 197 early stage of disease progression (0~7 d.a.o), while differential expressions of MIG and MIP-1α in the 198 later stages of disease progression (8~14 and ≥ 15 d.a.o). However, little differences were observed in 199 IL-6, IL-13, IL-18, IL-1β, CTACK, MIP-1β and G-CSF (Figure 1). 200 201 IP-10, MCP-3 and IL-1ra are independent predictors for the progression of COVID-19 202 Then, we further analyzed whether these cytokines could be used as predictors for the disease 203 progression of COVID-19. These patients were divided into the ARDS group which contained the 204 critically ill and severe patients, and the non-ARDS group which included the moderate patients. The 205 receiver operating characteristic (ROC) of each single cytokine was calculated using the expression 206 levels upon admission (Figure 2 and Figure S3). Results showed that the area under the curve (AUC) of 207 the ROC was 0.97 for IP-10, follow by IL-1ra of 0.866 and MCP-3 of 0.803 (Figure 2A). The AUC of 208 other cytokines varied from 0.565 to 0.767 (Figure 2A). Then we tested the different combination of 209 the three cytokines for the prediction of disease progression (Figure 2B). Combination of IP-10 and 210 MCP-3 showed the highest AUC of 0.99, followed by the combination of IP-10 and IL-1ra (0.976) as 211 well as the combination of MCP-3 and IL-1ra (0.857) (Figure 2B). Combinations of the three cytokines 212 showed the same AUC with combination of IP-10 and MCP-3. 213 214 Expression levels of IP-10, MCP-3, HGF, MIG and MIP-1α were highly associated with disease 215 severity and progression 216 Murray scores for evaluation of disease severity of COVID-19 from the corresponding date of sample 217 collection were recorded 26, 27 , and Spearman rank coefficient correlation analysis were done to analyze 218 the association between the expression levels of cytokines and the Murray scores. The results showed 219 that IP-10, MCP-3, HGF, MIG, IL-1ra and MIP-1α expression levels were highly and positively 220 correlated with Murray scores, with r values >0.45 and p values <0.0001 (Figure 3). While IL-1ra, 221 IL-2ra, IL-6, IL-10, IL-18, M-CSF and IFN-γ showed weaker, albeit significant, positive associations 222 with Murray scores (Figure 3).

FIGREF9.text: , we analyzed the dynamic change of the fourteen cytokines in 16 COVID-19 cases 224 with different disease severity, including 8 critically ill patients (cases 1~8), 5 severe patients (cases 225 9~13) and 3 moderate patients (cases 14~16)(Figure 4). Of the 8 critically ill patients, 2 cases (cases 1 226 and 2) passed away, 4 cases were in critical condition (cases 3~6) and the remaining 2 cases (cases 7 227 and 8) discharged from hospital. All the severe and moderate cases have discharged from hospital. In 228 the two fatal cases (cases 1 and 2), the expression levels of IP-10, MCP-3, HGF, MIG and MIP-1α 229 were significantly high upon admission and maintained high expression levels during the disease 230 progression(Figure 4). Meanwhile, the four cases still in critical condition (cases 7~9, 11 and 13) also 231 showed continuously high levels of these five cytokines, while lower than the fatal cases (Figure 4). On 232 the contrary, the two critically ill patients (cases 7 and 8) and all the severe and mild cases (cases 9~16) 233 who discharged from hospital showed lower levels or significantly decreased levels of the five 234 cytokines during disease progression (33 , and some preliminary studies have descriptively reported the immunologic 239 characteristics with limited number of cases 26, 32 . In this study, a total of 50 patients were included and 240 the relationships between expression levels of plasma cytokines and the disease severity as well as 241 progression were analyzed in detail. Consistent with previous study which has shown age to be a risk 242 factor for developing severe disease following SARS-CoV-2 infection 8, 30 , most of the severe and 243 critically ill patients were above 60 years-old(Table 1). CD4 and CD8 cells play vital roles in immune 244 responses, including immune regulation, cytokines secretion, virus-specific antibody production and 245 cytolytic activities against target cells 34 . Similar with SARS-CoV and MERS-CoV infections 35, 36 , 246 significantly lower CD4 and CD8 counts were observed in severe and critically ill COVID-19 patients 247 (Table S1), which indicated that a possible dysfunction of immune responses happened in these patients.248 Furthermore, virus specific CD4 response played vital roles in the control of SARS-CoV and 249 MERS-CoV infection 37, 38 . However, little is known about the role of T cells in the control of 250 SARS-CoV-2 patients currently, which merits further investigation.251 Thirty cytokines including both pro-and anti-inflammatory cytokines were found to be 252 significantly elevated upon admission, most of which were consistent with previous studies 25, 26 , 253 indicating that cytokine storm occurred in COVID-19 patients following SARS-CoV-2 infection 254 (Figure S1). Similar phenomenon was also observed in SARS-CoV 17-21 and MERS-CoV 22-24 infected 255 patients, despite that the expression profiles were virus specific. Of note, MCP-3, HGF, MIG and 256 MIP-1α showed no statistical differences between healthy controls and patients with moderate disease 257 at different stage of disease, while significant elevation of these cytokines was observed in both the severe and critically ill patients (Figure 1). Moreover, another evident trend was that expression levels 259 of IL-1ra, IL-6, M-CSF, HGF, IP-10, MCP-3, MIP-1α and MIG were the highest in critically ill patients, 260 followed by severe patients and then the moderate ones. This indicated that cytokine storm was 261 obviously stronger in the severe and critically ill patients. Using the expression levels of the 14 262 cytokines measured upon admission, we further tested whether some cytokines could be used as 263 biomarkers to predict the disease progression of COVID-19 (Figure 2). AUC of ROC for IP-10 was 264 0.97, and combination of IP-10 and MCP-3 showed a slightly higher value of 0.99, indicating that 265 combination of IP-10 and MCP-3 could predict the progression of COVID-19 more accurately (Figure 266 2). The results suggested that IP-10 and MCP-3 could be served as excellent biomarkers for the 267 prediction of COVID-19 progression, and further study with a separate cohort of patients is needed to 268 validate the association between elevated IP-10 and MCP-3 with critical disease.269 Comparison of the expression levels of the 14 cytokines measured from samples collected at270 different time-points of disease progression showed that differential expression of IP-10, MCP-3 and 271 HGF were found in all the three groups at all the stages of disease progression, while MIG and MIP-1α 272 mainly in the later stages (8~14 and ≥ 15 d.a.o) (Figure 1). Meanwhile, the evident trend that highest 273 expression levels in critically ill patients, followed by severe patients and then the moderate ones were 274 also found, indicating that these cytokines might associate with disease severity. Using Spearman rank 275 coefficient correlation analysis, we confirmed this hypothesis and found that the five cytokines showed 276 high correlation with disease severity (Figure 3). Furthermore, dynamic change of the five cytokines in 277 16 COVID-19 cases with different disease severity and outcome also showed a high association 278 between the expression levels of the five cytokines and the disease severity as well as outcome.279 Continuously high expression levels of the five cytokines resulted in adverse progression and even fatal outcome (Figure 4). Although there was a lot of overlap in cytokines levels between moderate and 281 severe cases for most cytokines measured, the six cytokines including IP-10, MCP-3, HGF, IL-1ra, 282 MIG and MIP-1α might play vital roles in disease progression of COVID-19. These results suggested 283 that these significantly elevated cytokines played important roles in the immunopathogenesis of 284 SARS-CoV-2 infection and associated with disease severity and outcome. 285 Cytokine storm with uncontrolled proinflammatory responses induce significant 286 immunopathology and severe disease outcomes during some viral infections, indicating an important 287 role in the pathogenesis of these viruses 2, 39 . Accordingly, not only the pathogens but also the pathogen 288 induced cytokine storm should be considered during the treatment. Therapy strategy with a 289 combination of antimicrobial and immunotherapy may produce a more favorable outcome 9 .290 Corticosteroids which could downregulate proinflammatory cytokine transcription and subsequently 291 inhibit the cytokine storm 40 , and the antiviral cytokine interferon-α were widely used in severe and 292 critically ill patients during the treatment of COVID-19 8, 30 . However, use of high-dose corticosteroids 293has been shown to be associated with an increase in mortality and significantly longer durations of viral 294 shedding in H7N9 infected patients 41 , which is of concern. Therefore, short courses of corticosteroids 295 at low to moderate dose were recommended 42 . Moreover, the results of our study suggested a crucial 296 roles of specific cytokines like IP-10 in the pathogenesis of SARS-CoV-2, which has also been shown 297 to be associated with disease severity of H5N1, H1N1, SARS-CoV and MERS-CoV 16, 24, 43, 44 . A recent 298 study has found that CXCL10 (IP-10)-CXCR3 signaling appears to be a critical factor for the 299 exacerbation of the pathology of ARDS 45 . Thus, modulators such as antibody targeting IP-10 might be 300 a promising therapeutic strategy in the treatment of the acute phase of ARDS to ameliorates acute lung 301 injury as shown in H1N1 mouse model45, 46  .severe and moderate COVID-19 cases in detail, and found that IP-10 and MCP-3 were highly 304 associated with disease severity and could be used as excellent predictors of COVID-19 progression.305Therefore, detecting the expression levels of IP-10 and MCP-3 in COVID-19 patients in the early stage 306 of the disease may provide useful information for the formulating of specific strategy of treatment. Our 307 results added to our understanding of the immunopathologic mechanisms of SARS-CoV-2 infection, 308 and provide potential therapeutic targets and strategies.

The fatal cases (cases 1 and 2) 449 were marked in red. Cases in critical condition at present (cases 3~6) were marked in blue, and the 450 other patients were discharged from hospital.
